posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Hello, I just had a. quick question about “normal” values for a PID controlled arm. I just wanted to check other people’s PID values to find a reasonable value for us.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: There is no “normal” value for PID.  It’s totally dependent on your desired value, actual value, mechanism gearing and resolution.

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: Its a property of the system, so it depends. Start very small (0.001 for P) and increase until you get small consistent oscillation, then add D (also start small) until it stops oscillating. No I gain, just dont.

posts.name: Saraansh Wadkar
posts.cooked:
There aren’t normal PID values per say but because PID values have actual units you can convert the seemingly magic numbers you’re passing to the spark into values that actually make sense (and as a result may seem normal).

For Sparkmaxes, refer to this .

It says kP is in normalized/native where normalized is power (-1 being full reverse throttle and 1 being max throttle) and native is native sensor units.

It says kI is in normalized/(native*ms) .

It says kD is in normalized/(native/ms)

Assuming you’re running position PID, you can effectively plug in your magic number into an equation to get a meaningful value that’s in Control Effort/Control Error where effort is something like volts or amps and error is something like radians or meters.

The equation is as follows for kP for a sparkmax.

?\frac{V}{rad}\ =\ \ x\frac{\ normalized}{rotations}\cdot\frac{12\ V}{1\ normalized}\ \cdot\ \frac{1\ rotation}{6.28\ rads}\cdot GR

The native units for the sparkmax for position are rotations and GR is a gear ratio where reduction   is greater than 1. This also assumes 12 V corresponds to full power–if you set your voltage compensation voltage to something different then that voltage should be replaced instead of 12.

You can alter this process for kI and kD and get numbers that make more sense. We also do it here for kI and here for kD . Ex: if you get a kP values like 1 Volt/degree then you know that that’s probably not right and you should lower your kP value (if it is right that’s fr fr crazy )

Reverse engineering the calculations that output your magic PID numbers can honestly give you a really good idea of how reasonable your values are. Ofc this is a lot of effort to do every time you tune them but it’s not all that bad to do if you’re questioning the validity of them.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Why don’t I add I gain?

posts.name: Robert
posts.cooked:
Because I is the reverse of D. Here are some great articles on control theory:

Learn about control theory and PID Controllers

https://blog.wesleyac.com/posts/intro-to-control-part-two-pid-tuning

link_counts.title: Wesley Aptekar-Cassels | Intro to Control Theory Part 1: PID
Wesley Aptekar-Cassels | Intro to Control Theory Part Two: PID tuning

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
I represents integration.  It’s the accumulation of error over time between setpoint and measurement.  D represents derivative.  It’s the rate of change of error between setpoint and measurement over time.  To the extent that the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus states that the derivative of the integral of a function is the same function, there is an inverse relationship between integral and derivative control modes.  However, this doesn’t provide any reason not to use the integral mode of PID control.

What integral buys you is the ability to remove steady-state error between setpoint and measurement.  For a non-integrating system, proportional control cannot remove all steady-state error.  For fast systems like those on most robots, proportional gain can be turned up high enough to eliminate almost all of the steady-state error to the point where control is acceptable.  The price you pay for using integral is instability of the control loop.  Too much integral will lead to oscillation of the system. Too much proportional gain will also lead to oscillation, but it comes on quicker through the use of integral.

The advice to try to avoid using integral, especially for those without background and experience in process control, is good advice due to the potential for instability.  Most FRC applications are fine without it.  In skilled hands and in the right application, integral mode can improve controller performance.
